## 12.2.1 Exercises {.unnumbered}

1.  The plot below shows the relationship between displacement and highway mileage with customized labels.


    ::: {.cell}
    
    ```{.r .cell-code}
    ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +
      geom_point(aes(color = class)) +
      geom_smooth(se = FALSE) +
      labs(
        title = "Fuel economy vs. engine displacement",
        subtitle = "For 38 popular models of cars",
        caption = "Source: https://fueleconomy.gov",
        x = "Engine displacement (L)",
        y = "Highway fuel economy (mpg)",
        color = "Car type"
      )
    #> `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'
    ```
    
    ::: {.cell-output-display}
    ![](communication_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=576}
    :::
    :::


2.  Below is the code for recreating the plot given.


    ::: {.cell}
    
    ```{.r .cell-code}
    ggplot(mpg, aes(x = cty, y = hwy, color = drv, shape = drv)) +
      geom_point() +
      labs(
        x = "City MPG",
        y = "Highway MPG",
        shape = "Type of\ndrive train",
        color = "Type of\ndrive train"
      )
    ```
    
    ::: {.cell-output-display}
    ![](communication_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=576}
    :::
    :::

3.  Geom text puts a label at each point on every facet.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_grid(vars(drv)) +
  geom_text(label = "a", nudge_y = 6)


ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.1) +
  facet_wrap(~drv) +
  geom_text(data = mpg |> 
              filter(drv == "f"), aes(label = drv), nudge_x = 1)



ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +
```

## 12.4.6 Exercises {.unnumbered}

1.  Because geom hex already fills this in you could use scale_fill instead.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
df <- tibble(
  x = rnorm(10000),
  y = rnorm(10000)
)

ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) +
  geom_hex() +
  scale_color_gradient(low = "black", high = "red") +
  coord_fixed()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](communication_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=576}
:::
:::


2.  Name or palette ,you can label your x and y axis with scale_x_continous and also labs.

3.  


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
presidential |>
  mutate(id = 33 + row_number()) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = start, y = id, color = party)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_segment(aes(xend = end, yend = id)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c(Republican = "#E81B23", Democratic = "#00AEF3")) +
    scale_x_date(name = "Term", breaks = seq(from = ymd("1953-01-20"), to = ymd("2021-01-20"), by = "4 years"), date_labels = "'%y") +
scale_y_continuous(
  name = "president",
  breaks = 34:45,
  labels = presidential$name
)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](communication_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=576}
:::
:::

```{.r .cell-code}

  geom_point() + 
  labs(title = "Plot 1")

  geom_boxplot() + 
  labs(title = "Plot 2")
```
